snippet: The European Commission rejected on Thursday Apple's criticism that an EU order to the company to pay back taxes to Ireland was political, noting the calculations were based on facts and Apple's own data.

headline.main: EU Says Apple Tax Ruling Not Political and Based on Apple Data
headline.print_headline: EU Says Apple Tax Ruling Not Political and Based on Apple Data

snippet: Other multinationals that do not employ as extreme Irish tax schemes as Apple Inc but shift profits via the country to tax havens could also be breaching EU rules, Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said on Thursday.

headline.main: EU's Vestager Warns Others, Says Apple Could Cut Bill
headline.print_headline: EU's Vestager Warns Others, Says Apple Could Cut Bill

snippet: Apple's chief executive says the company has put aside "several billion dollars" to pay tax liabilities in the United States as it repatriates some of its huge overseas earnings.

headline.main: Apple Says Several Billion Dollars Set Aside for US Taxes
headline.print_headline: Apple Says Several Billion Dollars Set Aside for US Taxes

snippet: The White House says President Barack Obama will lead a discussion of tax avoidance, spurred by the European Union's recent decision about Apple, during the G-20 summit of major economies.

headline.main: White House: Obama to Discuss Apple Taxes at G-20 Summit
headline.print_headline: White House: Obama to Discuss Apple Taxes at G-20 Summit

snippet: Lawmakers have criticized companies that avoid taxes by moving overseas. But they’re rallying to Apple’s defense after an E.U. demand for $14.5 billion in back taxes.
abstract: Treasury Dept is challenging European Union's bid to extract $14.5 billion in Irish back taxes from Apple, calling move 'deeply troubling' and 'act of aggression;' some angry politicians say money is due Treasury Dept.

headline.main: Yesterday, Outraged by Apple’s Tax Dodge. Today, by Its Tax Bill.
headline.print_headline: Apple, Once a Tax Outcast, Now Has Allies

snippet: The European Commission was right to order Apple to pay 13 billion euros ($14.48 billion) in back tax, French Finance Minister Michel Sapin said on Thursday, backing Brussels as tensions flare with Washington over the ruling.

headline.main: French Finance Minister Says 'Normal That Apple Should Pay Normal Taxes'
headline.print_headline: French Finance Minister Says 'Normal That Apple Should Pay Normal Taxes'

snippet: Apple expects to repatriate billions of dollars of global profits to the United States next year, Chief Executive Tim Cook said in a radio interview on Thursday, but did not specify exactly how much would be returned.

headline.main: Apple CEO Expects to Repatriate Billions of Dollars to U.S. Next Year
headline.print_headline: Apple CEO Expects to Repatriate Billions of Dollars to U.S. Next Year

snippet: A group of independent lawmakers in Ireland's government want their coalition partners to commit to reviewing how tax is collected from multinationals before it considers appealing an EU ruling against tax dealings with Apple.

headline.main: Independent Irish Ministers Want Review of Multinationals Tax
headline.print_headline: Independent Irish Ministers Want Review of Multinationals Tax

snippet: President Barack Obama will likely have discussions with world leaders at the upcoming G20 meeting in China about controlling corporate tax avoidance and creating a more fair global tax system, the White House said on Thursday.

headline.main: Obama Likely to Address Corporate Tax Avoidance at G20: White House
headline.print_headline: Obama Likely to Address Corporate Tax Avoidance at G20: White House

snippet: Apple's Chief Executive Tim Cook described an EU ruling that it must pay a huge tax bill to Ireland as "total political crap", but France joined Germany on Thursday in backing Brussels as transatlantic tensions grow.

headline.main: EU Ruling on Apple's Irish Tax Is 'Total Political Crap': CEO
headline.print_headline: EU Ruling on Apple's Irish Tax Is 'Total Political Crap': CEO
